docs.lead_paragraph: Women appear to be more likely than men to lie about their sexual history and practices, a new study reports. Women, the researchers say, sometimes minimize their sexual experience.
docs.abstract: Ohio State University study, conducted by Dr Terri D Fisher and Dr Michele G Alexander and published in Journal of Sex Research, finds that women and men have similar patterns of sexual behavior, but under certain survey conditions women will change their answers about involvement with sex to minimize their experience; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Women appear to be more likely than men to lie about their sexual history and practices, a new study reports.    Women, the researchers say, sometimes minimize their sexual experience.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dyslexia appears to be caused by two distinct types of brain problems, a new study has found. The researchers, from Yale, used scanning devices to examine the brains of 43 young adults with known reading disabilities while they performed reading tasks. Another group of 27 good readers were also studied.

headline.main: Two Types of Brain Problems Are Found to Cause Dyslexia

docs.abstract: Article on Yale researchers, led by Dr Sally E Shaywitz, study of brain activity in one group of children challenged by dyslexia and another group considered to be good readers; findings show that readers with disabilities fall into two distinct categories; one group of dyslexics shows type of disability that is primarily genetic in nature and other shows more environmentally influenced dyslexia; poorest readers appear to use memory as their primary aid in reading; research supports International Dyslexia Assn executive director J Thomas Viall's theory that disorder's cure is education and early, individual strategies are needed to teach each child successfully; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Dyslexia appears to be caused by two distinct types of brain problems, a new study has found.    The researchers, from Yale, used scanning devices to examine the brains of 43 young adults with known reading disabilities while they performed reading...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1995, Dr. Steven Miles, a well-known specialist in internal medicine at the University of Minnesota, fell into a deep depression. At night, he lay in bed unable to sleep. He became preoccupied with suicide. ''This bridge has a low railing,'' he would think, or, peering over a banister into a five-story drop, ''This is a convenient stairwell.''

headline.main: Doctors' Toughest Diagnosis: Own Mental Health

docs.abstract: American Foundation for Suicide Prevention workshop gathers doctors and other health professionals concerned about professions' lack of support for mental health issues; rate of depression among doctors matches that of general population and research suggests higher rate of suicide than average; medical training and practice emphasizes stamina and emotional resilience and does not leave time nor allow for professional inclination to seek help when it is needed; Dr Steven Miles, University of Minnesota internal medicine specialist, has fought personal battle to keep psychiatric records private when faced with licensing issues in his state; he, and others who attended seminar, writing in Journal of American Medical Association, stress importance of encouraging doctors to seek treatment for depression and are working to change system that penalizes those who do; photos (L)
docs.snippet: In the summer of 1995, Dr. Steven Miles, a well-known specialist in internal medicine at the University of Minnesota, fell into a deep depression.    At night, he lay in bed unable to sleep. He became preoccupied with suicide. ''This bridge has a low...

docs.lead_paragraph: Is golf the thinking athlete's game? Perhaps, but don't think too hard if you want to do well, a new study suggests. When golfers of differing abilities were asked to visualize their swings as an M.R.I. scanned their brains, the best golfers showed the least brain activity, researchers report in the current American Journal of Neuroradiology.
docs.abstract: Cleveland Clinic Foundation research study, headed by Dr Jeffrey S Ross and published in American Journal of Neuroradiology, indicates good golfers use less of their brains while visualizing their swing than less talented players; fact that only six golfers were studied may limit value of research; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Is golf the thinking athlete's game? Perhaps, but don't think too hard if you want to do well, a new study suggests.    When golfers of differing abilities were asked to visualize their swings as an M.R.I. scanned their brains, the best golfers...

docs.lead_paragraph: Preschool children who eat foods containing milk fat frequently appear less likely to suffer from asthma when they are older, Dutch researchers reported yesterday. Writing in the journal Thorax, the scientists said that 2-year-old children who regularly consumed whole milk and butter had a better chance of being asthma-free at 3. (Pediatricians in the United States normally suggest that children drink whole milk until the age of 2, and then drink 2 percent milk.)
docs.abstract: Dr A H Wijga of National Institute of Public Health and Environment in Netherlands publishes study in journal Thorax linking asthma and milk fat; findings show lower incidence of asthma in 3-year-olds if while they were 2-year-olds they consumed whole milk and butter on daily basis; study is part of ongoing effort to identify cause of childhood asthma increase; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Preschool children who eat foods containing milk fat frequently appear less likely to suffer from asthma when they are older, Dutch researchers reported yesterday.    Writing in the journal Thorax, the scientists said that 2-year-old children who...

docs.lead_paragraph: This recurring dream haunts me: I'm playing my violin in the youth orchestra, at the height of adolescent freedom, playing my heart out to Brahms or Mahler. Suddenly the notes become blurred. I edge forward, desperate to carry on. The notes slowly vanish. Defeated, I put my violin in its case and quietly slip away.

headline.main: Seeing Life In the Light Of Blindness

docs.abstract: Richard Lane Cases column on his personal journey from partially sighted teenager to blind man in his mid-twenties; his positive outlook for future remains buoyed by his lingering visual impressions from his youth (M)
docs.snippet: This recurring dream haunts me: I'm playing my violin in the youth orchestra, at the height of adolescent freedom, playing my heart out to Brahms or Mahler.    Suddenly the notes become blurred. I edge forward, desperate to carry on. The notes slowly...

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost a third of doctors surveyed said they had not told patients about useful treatments because they believed the patients' insurance would not cover them, a study reports today. The practice raises serious ethical issues and appears to be becoming more prevalent, researchers say in the journal Health Affairs.
docs.abstract: Dr Matthew K Wynia, infectious disease specialist and Institute for Ethics director at American Medical Assn, led survey published in journal Health Affairs that shows almost one-third of all doctors admit that they did not tell their patients about potentially beneficial treatments because they felt insurance would not cover them; pitfalls when doctors do not even allow patients their right to appeal denied coverage or choose to pay for treatment independent of coverage discussed (S)
docs.snippet: Almost a third of doctors surveyed said they had not told patients about useful treatments because they believed the patients' insurance would not cover them, a study reports today.     The practice raises serious ethical issues and appears to be...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Protecting America's Health,'' by Philip J. Hilts. Alfred A. Knopf, $26.95. ''A Managed Care Memoir,'' by Dr. Richard L. Reece. Infinity, $19.95.
docs.abstract: Books on Health column explores two books on health care that center on balance between corporate needs and consumer safety; book Protecting America's Health explains and evaluates Food and Drug Administration's more than one century of national care; book's author Philip J Hilts strongly supports public interest over private profits; Dr Richard L Reece book Managed Care Memoir provides guide through HMO's 20-year history and its impact on patient and doctor; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ''Protecting America's Health,'' by Philip J. Hilts. Alfred A. Knopf, $26.95.    ''A Managed Care Memoir,'' by Dr. Richard L. Reece. Infinity, $19.95.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1974, as part of an assignment, I read an eye-opening book, ''Type A Behavior and Your Heart.'' I was shocked to discover that I shared quite a few of the obnoxious -- and perhaps life-threatening -- traits typical of Type A behavior and vowed to make some changes. I learned, for example, to allow more time, not less, to get to places; not to leave important tasks to the last minute; and to resist doing one more thing before leaving the house, thus making myself anxious, and often late, even before starting out.

headline.main: Practicing Patience, a Virtue of Some Urgency

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column identifies impatience as habit not character flaw and gives practical advice from M J Ryan's book Power of Patience on ways to learn patience and thereby improve your health and outlook on life; holds that benefits of wait power as opposed to will power can influence overall health by reducing stress; contends that depersonalizing events and instead placing emphasis on larger picture along with reframing potentially stressful situations both help cultivate patience; reminds individuals of importance of good nutrition, adequate sleep and exercise to break down cycle of impatience steming from physical irritability; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: In 1974, as part of an assignment, I read an eye-opening book, ''Type A Behavior and Your Heart.'' I was shocked to discover that I shared quite a few of the obnoxious -- and perhaps life-threatening -- traits typical of Type A behavior and vowed to...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Jane Fowler made her way back into the dating scene in the early 1980's after her 23-year marriage ended in divorce, using a condom was not on her mind. She barely knew the word. ''Being from the 1950's, women like me thought condoms were only used for birth control,'' said Ms. Fowler, 68, a retired journalist and the director of the H.I.V. Wisdom for Older Women program in Kansas City, Kan. ''We didn't call them condoms anyway. If you said the word at all, you whispered 'rubber.' ''

headline.main: Raising Awareness About AIDS and the Aging

docs.abstract: Jim Campbell, National Association on HIV Over 50 president, voices concern that older people are not being educated about AIDS because general population does not view them as sexually active and therefore does not target group for information on prevention; from 1990 to end of 2001 number of AIDS cases in people 50-years-old or older went from 16,288 to 90,513 individuals; AIDS may be increasing within this population segment due to delayed diagnosis, increased vunerability to infection, societal constraints and lack of knowledge about disease, which emerged when many older adults were still in monogamous relationships; Miriam Schuler, who is known as Condom Grandma and who volunteers for Senior HIV Intervention Project in Ft Lauderdale (Florida), and Jane Fowler, director of HIV Wisdom for Older Women program, are hailed for their efforts; photos (M)
